{"Status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "Strong-lensing analysis of MS 1358.4+6245: New multiple images and implications for the well-resolved z= 4.92 galaxy", "authors": ["Zitrin, Adi", "Broadhurst, Tom", "Coe, Dan", "Liesenborgs, Jori", "Ben\u00edtez, Narciso", "Rephaeli, Yoel", "Ford, Holland", "Umetsu, Keiichi"], "author_address": ["AA(The School of Physics and Astronomy, the Raymond and Beverly Sackler Faculty of Exact Sciences, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel), AB(Department of Theoretical Physics, University of Basque Country UPV/EHU, Leioa, Spain; IKERBASQUE, Basque Foundation for Science, 48011 Bilbao, Spain), AC(Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, 4800 Oak Grove Dr, MS 169-327, Pasadena, CA 91109, USA), AD(Expertisecentrum voor Digitale Media, Universiteit Hasselt, Wetenschapspark 2, B-3590 Diepenbeek, Belgium), AE(Instituto de Astrof\u00edsica de Andaluc\u00eda (CSIC), C/Camino Bajo de Hu\u00e9tor, 24, Granada 18008, Spain), AF(The School of Physics and Astronomy, the Raymond and Beverly Sackler Faculty of Exact Sciences, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel), AG(Department of Physics and Astronomy, Johns Hopkins University, 3400 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21218, USA), AH(Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica, PO Box 23-141, Taipei 10617, Taiwan)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "413", "publication_year": "2011/05/1", "start_page": "1753", "end_page": "1763", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "galaxies: clusters: general", "galaxies: clusters: individual: MS 1358.4+6245", "galaxies: high-redshift", "dark matter", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Extragalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2011MNRAS.413.1753Z", "abstract": "We present a strong-lensing analysis of the galaxy cluster MS 1358.4+6245 (z= 0.33), in deep six-band HST/ACS imaging. In addition to the well-studied system at z= 4.92, our modelling method uncovers 19 new multiply lensed images belonging to seven background sources, so that a total of 23 images and their redshifts are used to accurately constrain the inner mass distribution. We derive a relatively shallow inner mass profile, d log \u03a3/d log r\u2243-0.33 \u00b1 0.05 (r < 200 kpc), with a much higher magnification than estimated previously by models constrained only by the z= 4.92 system. Using these many new images we can apply a non-parametric adaptive-grid method, which also yields a shallow mass profile without prior assumptions, strengthening our conclusions. The total magnification of the z<SUB>s</SUB>= 4.92 galaxy is high, about a \u223c100 times over its four images, so that the inferred source size, luminosity and star formation rate are about \u223c5 times smaller than previous estimates, corresponding to a dwarf-sized galaxy of radius \u22431 kpc. A detailed image of the interior morphology of the source is generated with a high effective resolution of only \u224350 pc, thanks to the high magnification and to the declining angular diameter distance above z\u223c 1.5 for the standard cosmology, so that this image apparently represents the best resolved object known at high redshift.", "doi": "10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1009.3936", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "3"}, "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2011MNRAS.413.1753Z", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": (!event.isEmpty) {\r\n                        $('.js-' + event.slot.getSlotElementId()).each(function () {\r\n                            if ($(this).find('iframe').length) {\r\n                                $(this).removeClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                        });\r\n                    }\r\n                });\r\n\r\n event.slot.getSlotElementId()).each(function () {\r\n                            var $adblockDiv = $(this).find('.js-adblock');\r\n                            var $adText = $(this).find('.js-adblock-advertisement-text');\r\n                            if ($adblockDiv && $adblockDiv.is(':visible') && $adblockDiv.find('*').length > 1) {\r\n                                $adText.removeClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                            else {\r\n                                $adText.addClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                        });\r\n                    }\r\n                });\r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlspage\", \"article\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlsurl\", \"mnras/article/413/3/1753/964883\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();\r\n                googletag.pubads().collapseEmptyDivs();\r\n            });\r\n        </script>\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n        <script type=\"text/javascript\">\r\n googletag.enableServices();\r\n                });\r\n        </script>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    <script>\r\n        var oupcookiepolicy_siteid = \"journals\";        // the website                                    </span>\r\n                                </span>\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name js-linked-name-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\">Yoel Rephaeli</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input          </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16570262 id=\"16570262\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a strong-lensing analysis of the galaxy cluster MS 1358.4+6245 (<em>z</em>= 0.33), in deep six-band <em>HST</em>/ACS imaging. In addition to the well-studied system at <em>z</em>= 4.92, our modelling method uncovers 19 new multiply lensed images belonging to seven background sources, so that a total of 23 images and their redshifts are used to accurately constrain the inner mass distribution. We derive a relatively shallow inner mass profile, d log \u03a3/d log <em>r</em>\u2243\u22120.33 \u00b1 0.05 (<em>r</em> &lt; 200 kpc), with a much higher magnification than estimated previously by models constrained only by the <em>z</em>= 4.92 system. Using these many new images we can apply a non-parametric adaptive-grid method, which also yields a shallow mass profile without prior assumptions, strengthening our conclusions. The total magnification of the <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 4.92 galaxy is high, about a \u223c100 times over its four images, so that the inferred source size, luminosity and star formation rate are about \u223c5 times smaller than previous estimates, corresponding to a dwarf-sized galaxy of radius \u22431 kpc. A detailed image of the interior morphology of the source is generated with a high effective resolution of only \u224350 pc, thanks to the high magnification and to the declining angular diameter distance above <em>z</em>\u223c 1.5 for the standard cosmology, so that this image apparently represents the best resolved object known at high redshift.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual: MS 1358.4+6245&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual: MS 1358.4+6245</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16570264 id=\"16570264\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxy cluster MS 1358.4+6245 (also known as CL 1358+62; hereafter MS 1358) was first identified by Zwicky &amp; Herzog (1968), and later classified as an X-ray luminous, rich cluster by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Luppino et al. (1991)</a> based on observations from the <em>Einstein Observatory</em> Extended Medium-Sensitivity Survey (EMSS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gioia et al. 1990</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b83\" data-open=\"b83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Stocke et al. 1991</a>). This cluster has been subject to intensive study, mainly due to its high X-ray luminosity and richness at an intermediate-high redshift (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Henry et al. 1992</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b22\" data-open=\"b22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Carlberg et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b76\" data-open=\"b76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Poggianti &amp; Barbaro 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Mushotzky &amp; Scharf 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kelson et al. 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b73\" data-open=\"b73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Nichol et al. 1997</a>), but became particularly famous when a pair of <em>z</em> = 4.92 lensed galaxies were uncovered in its inner region by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. (1997)</a>. Subsequently, other such high-<em>z</em> galaxies have been found in systematic surveys of galaxy clusters and in deep field imaging (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Frye &amp; Broadhurst 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b38\" data-open=\"b38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Frye, Broadhurst &amp; Ben\u00edtez 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b82\" data-open=\"b82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Stark et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bouwens et al. 2004</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b15\" data-open=\"b15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b16\" data-open=\"b16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bradley et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b95\" data-open=\"b95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zheng et al. 2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnified objects are particularly useful, being generally bright enough to yield useful spectra, in particular the <em>z</em> = 4.92 system in MS 1358 which has an especially well-resolved large fold image straddling the tangential critical curve. Detailed spectroscopy by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al.</a> (1997; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Swinbank et al. 2009</a>) has revealed asymmetric and redward-shifted Lyman \u03b1 emission relative to metal absorption lines, which is claimed to imply this galaxy is suffering an outflow of metal enriched gas (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. 1997</a>), similar to local dwarf starburst galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b26\" data-open=\"b26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dekel &amp; Silk 1986</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Heckman, Armus &amp; Miley 1990</a>). This spectral signature of gas outflow was shown to be a general property of <em>z</em> &gt; 4 galaxies, in the larger sample of lensed galaxies behind eight massive clusters, by Frye, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b32\" data-open=\"b32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Ben\u00edtez (2002)</a>, with implications for the enrichment of the IGM in general (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b81\" data-open=\"b81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Scannapieco &amp; Broadhurst 2001</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the past two decades, other extensive studies have included or focused on MS 1358, ranging from X-ray to radio measurements and scaling relations (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b21\" data-open=\"b21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Cagnoni, della Ceca &amp; Maccacaro 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b25\" data-open=\"b25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Cooray et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ettori &amp; Fabian 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wu 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">B\u00f6hringer et al. 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Arabadjis, Bautz &amp; Garmire 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brown et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">McCarthy et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Egami et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Laroque et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b69\" data-open=\"b69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Morandi, Ettori &amp; Moscardini 2007</a>), to intracluster content and evolution studies (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b90\" data-open=\"b90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">van Dokkum et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Borgani et al. 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b32\" data-open=\"b32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Fabricant, Franx &amp; van Dokkum 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b33\" data-open=\"b33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ferreras &amp; Silk 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Henry 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b54\" data-open=\"b54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kochanek et al. 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kelson et al. 2000a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b86\" data-open=\"b86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tran et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b77\" data-open=\"b77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Postman et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b47\" data-open=\"b47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Holden et al. 2007</a>), and arc statistics and searches (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b56\" data-open=\"b56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Le F\u00e8vre et al. 1994</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b41\" data-open=\"b41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hattori, Watanabe &amp; Yamashita 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b63\" data-open=\"b63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Luppino et al. 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b74\" data-open=\"b74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri, Lee &amp; Suto 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b91\" data-open=\"b91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wambsganss, Bode &amp; Ostriker 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b80\" data-open=\"b80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al. 2005</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Despite this broad study, only one multiply lensed system has been hitherto identified in this cluster (the <em>z</em> = 4.92 dropout galaxy; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. 1997</a>), so that no full strong lensing (SL) analysis has been possible given the wide degeneracy of models with so few images. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. (1997)</a> presented a SL mass model based on the <em>z</em> = 4.92 dropout galaxy they uncovered, and various simplified mass models were used by others (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b68\" data-open=\"b68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Molikawa et al. 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b92\" data-open=\"b92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Williams, Navarro &amp; Bartelmann 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b79\" data-open=\"b79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Saha, Williams &amp; Abdelsalam 2001</a>), often based on isothermal potentials or spherical symmetry. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b101\" data-open=\"b101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al.</a> (2008; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Swinbank et al. 2009</a>) presented two <em>z</em>\u223c 7.5 unverified multiply lensed candidates for which Lyman \u03b1 emission has not been detected. Moreover, we note that for a cluster at <em>z</em><sub>cl</sub> = 0.33, the lensing-distance ratio for sources at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 and <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 7.5 differs by only \u223c2 per cent, so that in order to meaningfully constrain the inner mass profile it is crucial to use other multiply lensed systems at lower redshifts to expand the range of lensing distances.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here we use our well-tested approach to modelling in order to find a significant number of multiple images across the central field of MS 1358 so that the mass distribution <em>and its profile</em> can be well constrained. This method was developed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2005a)</a>, and simplified further by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. (2009b)</a> and has securely identified tens of multiple images in high-quality <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>)/Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) images, of background sources behind several clusters with deep <em>HST</em>/ACS imaging, including Abell 1689; Cl0024+17 and a sample of 12 MACS clusters at <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b99\" data-open=\"b99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2011</a>). This is done with only six free parameters so that in practice the number of multiple images uncovered readily exceeds the number of free parameters as minimally required in order to obtain a reliable fit.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This approach to lens-modelling is based on the reasonable assumption that mass approximately traces light. Recently we have independently tested this assumption in Abell 1703 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b100\" data-open=\"b100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2010</a>), by applying the non-parametric technique of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs, De Rijcke &amp; Dejonghe (2006)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. (2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009)</a> for comparison, which is also employed here. This latter technique employs an adaptive grid inversion method and does not require prior assumptions regarding the mass distribution, relying only on the images we have identified and their redshift estimates. For meaningful constraints, this approach to modelling requires many sets of multiple images, and over a wide range of background redshifts per cluster. This condition is well met for A1703 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b100\" data-open=\"b100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2010</a>) and this model-independent method yields a very similar mass distribution to our parametric technique in the case of A1703, supporting the assumption that mass generally traces light. Independently, it has been found that SL methods based on parametric modelling are accurate at the level of a few per cent in determining the projected inner mass (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b66\" data-open=\"b66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti et al. 2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results of this work will be further combined with a wide-range weak lensing (WL) data from deep Subaru imaging to provide the cluster mass profile out to the virial radius and beyond (Umetsu et al., in preparation). To date only a few clusters have been reliably analysed by combining both weak and SL for a full determination of the mass profile and a definitive comparison with theoretical predictions, (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gavazzi et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005b</a>, 2008; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b67\" data-open=\"b67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Merten et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b72\" data-open=\"b72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Newman et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b75\" data-open=\"b75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010</a>, and references therein, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b87\" data-open=\"b87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2010a</a>,b; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b100\" data-open=\"b100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2010</a>). The upcoming multicycle <em>HST</em> programme of cluster imaging (the CLASH programme<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a>) will provide a much more definitive derivation of mass profiles for a statistical sample of relaxed, X-ray selected clusters, combining high-resolution space imaging with deep, wide-field ground-based data, for a definitive determination of the equilibrium mass profiles of virialized clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Luppino et al. (1991)</a> measured the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) of MS 1358 at a redshift of <em>z</em> = 0.323. Other spectroscopic studies of many cluster member galaxies suggest a similar cluster redshift of <em>z</em>\u2243 0.33, which is the redshift adopted here (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Fabricant, McClintock &amp; Bautz 1991</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b22\" data-open=\"b22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Carlberg et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Fisher et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b94\" data-open=\"b94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Yee et al. 1998</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The paper is organized as follows. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a> we describe the observations. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a> we detail the SL analysis and in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a> we report and discuss the results, which are then summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5\"></span><a href=\"#ss5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5</a>. Throughout this paper, we adopt a concordance \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) cosmology with (\u03a9<sub>m0</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b0</sub> = 0.7, <em>h</em> = 0.7). With these parameters, 1 arcsec corresponds to a physical scale of 4.75 kpc for this cluster (at <em>z</em> = 0.33). The reference centre of our analysis is fixed at the centre of the BCG: RA = 13:59:50.55 Dec. =+62:31:05.00 (J2000.0).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16570274 id=\"16570274\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2>2 OBSERVATIONS AND PHOTOMETRIC REDSHIFTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MS 1358 was observed with the Wide Field Channel (WFC) of the ACS installed on <em>HST</em> in the framework of the ACS Guaranteed Time Observations (GTO; PI: Ford, H.; programme IDs 9292, 9717, 10325) which includes deep observations of several massive, intermediate-redshift galaxy clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ford et al. 2003</a>). Integration times of 7928, 5470, 5482, 9196, 13552 and 17757 s were obtained through the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>475<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>555<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>625<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>775<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>850<em>LP</em> (<em>Bg</em>\u2032<em>Vr</em>\u2032<em>i</em>\u2032<em>z</em>\u2032) filters, respectively. Some important aims of the GTO programme were the determination of the mass distribution of clusters for testing the standard cosmological model and to study distant, background lensed galaxies for which some of the very highest redshift galaxies are found because of high magnification by massive clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass models and detailed lensing analyses have been presented for most of the GTO clusters (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jee et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b61\" data-open=\"b61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lemze et al. 2008</a>, 2011; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b61\" data-open=\"b61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b78\" data-open=\"b78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2009</a>, 2010b; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coe et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b65\" data-open=\"b65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Medezinski et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b87\" data-open=\"b87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2010a</a>,b). In this work, we present a SL analysis of the ACS images of MS 1358 and detect several multiple-image systems, so the mass profile of this cluster can be reliably constrained as well.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The ACS images were initially reduced, processed and analysed by APSIS, the ACS GTO pipeline (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b8\" data-open=\"b8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Blakeslee et al. 2003</a>). An optimal \u03c7<sup>2</sup> detection image was created as a weighted sum of all filters, each divided by its background rms. Objects were detected and photometry obtained using SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The light of cluster galaxies was carefully modelled in each filter and subtracted from the images. This improves both the detection and photometry of lensed background objects. Based on this <em>Bg</em>\u2032<em>Vr</em>\u2032<em>i</em>\u2032<em>z</em>\u2032 photometry, we obtain photometric redshifts using BPZ (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ben\u00edtez 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b5\" data-open=\"b5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ben\u00edtez et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b23\" data-open=\"b23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coe et al. 2006</a>). The distances to the galaxies are, of course, key ingredients to the lens model.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16570279 id=\"16570279\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3>3 STRONG LENSING MODELLING AND ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We apply our well-tested approach to lens modelling, which has previously uncovered large numbers of multiply lensed galaxies in ACS images of Abell 1689, Cl0024 and 12 high-<em>z</em> MACS clusters, respectively (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>; Zitrin &amp; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009a</a>, 2010, 2011). Briefly, the basic assumption adopted is that mass approximately traces light, so that the photometry of the red cluster member galaxies is used as the starting point for our model. Cluster member galaxies are identified as lying close to the cluster sequence by the photometry described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a>.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We approximate the large-scale distribution of cluster mass by assigning a power-law mass profile to each galaxy (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>), the sum of which is then smoothed (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>). The degree of smoothing (<em>S</em>) and the index of the power law (<em>q</em>) are the most important free parameters determining the mass profile. A worthwhile improvement in fitting the location of the lensed images is generally found by expanding to first order the gravitational potential of this smooth component, equivalent to a coherent shear describing the overall matter ellipticity, where the direction of the shear and its amplitude are free parameters, allowing for some flexibility in the relation between the distribution of DM and the distribution of galaxies, which cannot be expected to trace each other in detail. The total deflection field <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-mu1.gif?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=e252Q8p5PcA6GKJ0n8KdYQhok2etGEmzGyGGIlQOj-cZGM2T4uOoydknxtHvkpj8Bh40aGQ3g4jlTUMq7ZLCK8BJLik1szOQVxD9s80goR4IyVul16qtMR~i4JdSsVFyVQhVSwP6EmjO-iL5vQP3AUZiaNxEGVYdAUUYB4kf6AZEG8NZuUwOqVdf8QabP-cbztRW-bt57lxt9Jt1WfTtqON2NG-cAS5NCKuvq-BUY~5FV12keL5uBRGIh7uKt96EQPzX1jVERhF3lY8PdrDYc3ze9qgEVj9byqhM6opY9pCWfPCBTl~gMHpIJcn6DmIRVjGTt-ex2b2GNI9hIb6CNw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0413-1753-m2.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-m2.gif?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=nExior5uPvM1JRpp669-e~F4XrbgPYT4WSHKN1dbQWiJrCZzXu8ZofpDXoWbtqS-TmEXDem46GBVfO98k8Py8wm2MLbHdrxUQ1evfP3i5GPAtwncSnE2JB240NMMUrgz8qEcRCTmkJxU7KMPTMzQFcBErOqi~Z4fvrUmYG0dwpaqEPPjrzVOOZFVRkZ2mJJ74PsLhiT~mv5wBjL1ujL3p0o6REs9fcOIHg-ZYmcLdCar4Zd2VRSboq4JxWOrxpyxck4xq-8MnfEJeUk6eOq6bXWYD2X0243IiWXcGyclQj3k47lh4oWNelcUvvUIvIpY4ykcAt5z-GQ7n46DjQi2cg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-m2.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">2</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m3\" content-id=\"m3\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0413-1753-m3.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-m3.gif?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=thBgbEArsJBpBvPowqV31v7ZzIiyWDfShZTD8tduef6iHPAEkviypqY-22JOtSRABbO~m9J9KJK7CdW6W0ZtbwnuN98g8Ss03yLDMMWfFxI1YyTaM~eqBmucGmRdnESpy~unUl5Ar88APDdvSseKI3szSuOhd29S15ngXecaKZv4l4vjgQ1mabykXDmyUBjxa~FnQ60DgM04RO2WHHODr2iqaHYjd1kHHXWmJqiPq0l2pvBaafWRWdjc~CGp254B0EQpdGu9JcxfEI0pNDnV3rR0N6MXs~tx~kOf-N~BMswCoiudCWHjm9UdWJJtvL86ALPUyocGaD-jOFm4ToObqg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" displacement vector of the position <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-mu7.gif?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=t1nHbe4ExDY4kwWPZ~LjrTpERDMwKAqvSoUN7Zr7sw9fTz~cB2WLt0ifzdzBFFCA-i58cE~GJKajMJVdQcbfsEkchPsBbntU9QO29RA4DPij2eMjBhWDvq27nmTNdnKTN2spM17EZXBLPq9WiMUzyRh-N5nfhIIroCgUiGtoTPwRumWH~6zc5b8~-LEeG6j-OrxMrU8vKQqfg4c8Mahr7XAGR2vf7qiEVQXIgFXXgtkTx5zk-uJVaVrxVgQQXMgcvYoyP3fimHiFEqox7GP7fZ7QV1vDXmQX07ojcXbk8Vk78wepzPSyFS4snGd2dAr7kkZeMswgdtdBNnxb66WJug__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-mu7.gif\" /></span> with respect to a fiducial reference position, which we take as the lower left pixel position (1, 1), and \u03d5<sub>\u03b3</sub> is the position angle of the spin-2 external gravitational shear measured anti-clockwise from the <em>x</em>-axis. The normalization of the model and the relative scaling of the smooth DM component versus the galaxy contribution, along with the power-law index, the smoothing degree and the two shear parameters bring the total number of free parameters in the model to six. This approach to SL is sufficient to accurately predict the locations and internal structure of multiple images, since in practice the number of multiple images uncovered readily exceeds the number of free parameters thus fully constraining them.</div>                        <a id=\"16570283\" scrollto-destination=\"16570283\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=Dk0YMi2J7Ta7K9MbdpVpMH5Izx2vP9yrHZoCpRVUQ4cLZMiaaglMxN2YGrrQVQ7fHAUz~HepF6gw5PgKU9kFfFDh6yvkOJgelmxCcFOOuBwT5rb29qPjY7T45vc9NvLhg6-BY9z1P77iJa6WV1F9W0MDIU9K2Nj2SDsCfCdDTCs3Aus6O5pRjxEfTiJYRpBTExL3gXnzID2mf~VnThNjJf40LTPtH3CRcgsth3Nt8OorAz4UFPxbxTtPAiWtfuZQGnPFtVGvT--clvdhUJxMRqnMFwMbidKZ0uNukm0LrHfrqYqEIYz~vIOdZP04ejDmjXne7yJq4aMQzzPF9ZyuRg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The starting point of the mass model, where we define the surface mass distribution based on the cluster member galaxies (see Section 3). Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel\u22121).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570283/mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570283\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=ymYTHGDhhl26-oWg3A55FXqs3qoerhXGKTEmfzkWhdKq3Ba9V~mgnMZOOg7gxHmBteNNynzSEupO3oBpfynSxWBHBjN52w2Sr92BXZDiL5YgL2EnV7nQnRCTAj4t4NAzZ1Ttnkal3oy5fLNBEfDU9sB4sjcd0JGSYzUduGRDhhIW-WTxWAhere68r6z8~1SePtAd0lO1YUK8I92YLyIrCIZuROyt1xiGbPr85x-TwUK5MnimvmCRp~44vIzCyO8FJ1zsJedWYfac2LgHruUDf-BPKZgvmFent0GZJEn8Hm9hMditiIIidiWtJJILtmPwVaEd4DfzAZEkY88k4uoQ0A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570283&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The starting point of the mass model, where we define the surface mass distribution based on the cluster member galaxies (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>). Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=Dk0YMi2J7Ta7K9MbdpVpMH5Izx2vP9yrHZoCpRVUQ4cLZMiaaglMxN2YGrrQVQ7fHAUz~HepF6gw5PgKU9kFfFDh6yvkOJgelmxCcFOOuBwT5rb29qPjY7T45vc9NvLhg6-BY9z1P77iJa6WV1F9W0MDIU9K2Nj2SDsCfCdDTCs3Aus6O5pRjxEfTiJYRpBTExL3gXnzID2mf~VnThNjJf40LTPtH3CRcgsth3Nt8OorAz4UFPxbxTtPAiWtfuZQGnPFtVGvT--clvdhUJxMRqnMFwMbidKZ0uNukm0LrHfrqYqEIYz~vIOdZP04ejDmjXne7yJq4aMQzzPF9ZyuRg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The starting point of the mass model, where we define the surface mass distribution based on the cluster member galaxies (see Section 3). Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel\u22121).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570283/mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570283\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=ymYTHGDhhl26-oWg3A55FXqs3qoerhXGKTEmfzkWhdKq3Ba9V~mgnMZOOg7gxHmBteNNynzSEupO3oBpfynSxWBHBjN52w2Sr92BXZDiL5YgL2EnV7nQnRCTAj4t4NAzZ1Ttnkal3oy5fLNBEfDU9sB4sjcd0JGSYzUduGRDhhIW-WTxWAhere68r6z8~1SePtAd0lO1YUK8I92YLyIrCIZuROyt1xiGbPr85x-TwUK5MnimvmCRp~44vIzCyO8FJ1zsJedWYfac2LgHruUDf-BPKZgvmFent0GZJEn8Hm9hMditiIIidiWtJJILtmPwVaEd4DfzAZEkY88k4uoQ0A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570283&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The starting point of the mass model, where we define the surface mass distribution based on the cluster member galaxies (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>). Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>).</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"16570284\" scrollto-destination=\"16570284\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=GoB~lFZ1baRE9Y3VrngFamUeAxK3gG0PDu~m25-YHtGO8IUZnro6HHzz1Or0O5Qudfki~m3YTWCZ1kfxkNP0xmFCoifJoo1v3k3w3A16vkNGw~RGAuIKqgtEZ5dliMPGejjjUnB3CBq0v5tAUf7Wt6vUpkJCDZC7iZvEiX7CyFmgwAFlblYKilOCZmUrQrOl8jwN8e8gki029K4asUQ7H5WALC4U1BImcQqGxJWmbD3mBxrDwj9Ky0yRrxCHGS56RAXPZg8CoqF1v0LHJ0WcFzdBebJKPHAIlFS30sGqVmrps1vfK4~IfwREKgMN-39dVBz3V8tbNeea7Y8dGNoTlw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The resulting smooth mass component of the mass model (see Section 3). Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel\u22121).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570284/mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570284\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=xjiWl5nB-Y~bbDRs-RO57F445SCFzG5D4YQ2XrSW9XemdJA07CKaSF-8y6UtI9m3MiaTd07nwDkKzoV6IaiZ3~YCtjl04TNzD5eRmut2Y7nFdeuTIbtjtGOhyvW7yy1KvYQzJcmoSXe~KVZj~vz5kdUC2~6lR9QQyJF33JUEI0IE1modUanR2MGW4tyi9VpqBoBFv2ACNTf5zN9O-ikZxr7APyfjojLSedfd6yW-iJ404c5gIcU~YG~VWVQ9jdH0bt9Lsm-0xugJ0lQh8DbHdKDVjHKcmZ3qzLTx1FraHHywnx2MHaEniUGXcV-fWXl-Mie5PxLkt2iWVWhxv0axYg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570284&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The resulting smooth mass component of the mass model (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>). Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=GoB~lFZ1baRE9Y3VrngFamUeAxK3gG0PDu~m25-YHtGO8IUZnro6HHzz1Or0O5Qudfki~m3YTWCZ1kfxkNP0xmFCoifJoo1v3k3w3A16vkNGw~RGAuIKqgtEZ5dliMPGejjjUnB3CBq0v5tAUf7Wt6vUpkJCDZC7iZvEiX7CyFmgwAFlblYKilOCZmUrQrOl8jwN8e8gki029K4asUQ7H5WALC4U1BImcQqGxJWmbD3mBxrDwj9Ky0yRrxCHGS56RAXPZg8CoqF1v0LHJ0WcFzdBebJKPHAIlFS30sGqVmrps1vfK4~IfwREKgMN-39dVBz3V8tbNeea7Y8dGNoTlw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The resulting smooth mass component of the mass model (see Section 3). Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel\u22121).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570284/mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570284\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=xjiWl5nB-Y~bbDRs-RO57F445SCFzG5D4YQ2XrSW9XemdJA07CKaSF-8y6UtI9m3MiaTd07nwDkKzoV6IaiZ3~YCtjl04TNzD5eRmut2Y7nFdeuTIbtjtGOhyvW7yy1KvYQzJcmoSXe~KVZj~vz5kdUC2~6lR9QQyJF33JUEI0IE1modUanR2MGW4tyi9VpqBoBFv2ACNTf5zN9O-ikZxr7APyfjojLSedfd6yW-iJ404c5gIcU~YG~VWVQ9jdH0bt9Lsm-0xugJ0lQh8DbHdKDVjHKcmZ3qzLTx1FraHHywnx2MHaEniUGXcV-fWXl-Mie5PxLkt2iWVWhxv0axYg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570284&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The resulting smooth mass component of the mass model (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>). Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition, two of the six free parameters, namely the galaxy power-law index <em>q</em> and the smoothing degree <em>S</em>, can be primarily set to reasonable values so that only four of the free parameters have to be constrained initially, which sets a very reliable starting-point using obvious systems. The mass distribution is therefore primarily well constrained, uncovering many multiple images which can then be iteratively incorporated into the model, by using their redshift estimation and location in the image plane.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">First we use this preliminary model to lens the more obvious lensed galaxies back to the source plane by subtracting the derived deflection field, and then relens the source plane to predict the detailed appearance and location of additional counter images, which may then be identified in the data by morphology, internal structure and colour. We stress that multiple images found this way must be accurately reproduced by our model and are not simply eyeball \u2018candidates\u2019 requiring redshift verification. The best fit is assessed by the minimum rms uncertainty in the image plane: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m4\" content-id=\"m4\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0413-1753-m4.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-m4.gif?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=Eyyv2q-c6J-NRYSB-nmBykKeuNwPn9MvqmDAHQvcdD33YTXKkLd1Bgk5CuhFNdLafG3dlkeW7q3zL1akSqoHisjIw7zsRyfuyIycBvOpivPhYe7R27x3joLUksGAH~55zA-S3W-ZX11n0W3pGFhQOOlLraMEe2E52reMPrnn9rPVF88mES-PvtDP6QuSZH-9GGoigp6pINxjUGfs~Ap~GDAXZeRgMAQEOdAV47o58caxIyJeXXjALEHPTaqx9vxjPx0qJGaNxIubzSV3gJ~CBnKCI75PFhCPXkd-TkL5bAnhjfFmzFWqqoSrVkN08wJuNOQK7p4s0L6szEfh3HkWfA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-m4.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">4</span></div> where <em>x</em>\u2032<sub><em>i</em></sub> and <em>y</em>\u2032<sub><em>i</em></sub> are the locations given by the model, and <em>x<sub>i</sub></em> and <em>y<sub>i</sub></em> are the real image locations, and the sum is over all <em>N</em><sub>images</sub> images. The best-fitting solution is unique in this context, and the model uncertainty is determined by the location of predicted images in the image plane. Importantly, this image-plane minimization does not suffer from the well-known bias involved with source plane minimization, where solutions are biased by minimal scatter towards shallow mass profiles with correspondingly higher magnification.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The model is successively refined as additional sets of multiple images are incorporated to improve the fit, importantly using also their redshift information for better constraining the mass slope through the cosmological relation of the <em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub> growth.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to examine our results, we also apply the adaptive-grid, non-parametric modelling method of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. (2006</a>, 2007, 2009), which makes no prior assumptions regarding the mass distribution. In a recent work, we have made a more thorough comparison of these methods by analysing the well-studied cluster Abell 1703 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b100\" data-open=\"b100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2010</a>). We showed that the results of these two distinct approaches are very similar when sufficient data constraints are available. The effective area modelled with the non-parametric technique is limited to roughly the critical area, beyond which there are very few multiple images that can be used to reliably constrain the fit.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Some discrepancy may be expected with regards to the mass distribution between the two methods, especially when not enough constraints are available. In particular, non-parametric methods usually require a large number of constraints in order to derive an accurate and detailed 2D mass map. However, aside from minor local trade-offs originating in the mass-sheet degeneracy or in the inclusion of cluster members, the overall profile can be expected to be similar in order to maintain the cosmological lensing-distance ratio of the various systems.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16570290 id=\"16570290\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4>4 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16570291 id=\"16570291\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1>4.1 Multiple images, mass model and critical curves</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the four previously known lensed images of the <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 dropout galaxy (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. 1997</a>), our modelling technique has uncovered 19 new multiply lensed images in the central field of MS 1358, belonging to seven new systems. We have made use of the location and photometric redshift information of these images to fully constrain the mass model. We find that the critical curves for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 (system 1) enclose an area with an effective Einstein radius of <em>r</em><sub>E</sub> = 21 \u00b1 3 arcsec or \u2243100 kpc at the redshift of the cluster. This critical curve we find (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>) encloses a projected mass of <em>M</em>\u2243 6.1 \u00b1 0.8 \u00d7 10<sup>13</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. For a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 2, the effective Einstein radius is <em>r</em><sub>E</sub> = 13 \u00b1 2 arcsec, enclosing a projected mass of <em>M</em>\u2243 2.7 \u00b1 0.2 \u00d7 10<sup>13</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> around the BCG. For general comparison, this is in very good agreement with the Einstein radius\u2013mass scaling relation for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 2, found in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b99\" data-open=\"b99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2011</a> (taking into account also the different lens distances; see fig. 27 therein). The corresponding critical curves are plotted on the cluster image in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a> along with the multiply lensed systems. The resulting mass distribution and its profile are shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f4\" data-open=\"f4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 4</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"16570293\" scrollto-destination=\"16570293\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=hUf1DqygaZgFPRwilIzY-8PSDwMVawY8t4a87bYKDXIvCx3g-ei67HXE2oI1wVrV9C84WTbN1vYKW-gHrFN-oRNODbGxQi8D5yDBjJKuhA5qjE~IUarLm98ekPc58G0HNilHjbkfSRatvF9wZ~KUL~WWAqowCzgGDD8PETBQpEa1kNJHgeCuYdrWaDq2Q2YzHqp74JPccXh8U5qlO-e9UsXBCSIv-lnvFZBKjsEVPv8sztY33IakMFCWsVlt7mF~wTgbuQQcU1kbRs4vFcp~WmPHGMBFKltNL8bMMfTSDPd7V70BUNPbJFHJ~6QGBOwSQZaqw~7gPKiVSs38QrEbLA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Galaxy cluster MS 1358 (z = 0.33) imaged with HST/ACS. We number the multiply lensed images used and uncovered in this work. The overlaid white critical curve corresponds to system 1, the red dropout galaxy at zs = 4.92 (found by Franx et al. 1997), enclosing a critical area of an effective Einstein radius of \u2243100 kpc at the redshift of this cluster. Interior to this, the blue critical curves correspond to systems 3, 4, 5, at a lower redshift of zs\u223c 2. Additional less secure candidate systems (marked with \u2018c\u2019) have similar appearance but are not well reproduced by our best-fitting solution, and were not used to constrain the model. We also show the approximate location of two unverified candidate zs\u223c 7.5 multiple-systems, marked with \u2018z\u2019 (Richard et al. 2008). These were not used to constrain the model but their locations and claimed high redshift are plausible in the context of our model, see Section 4.1.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570293/mnras0413-1753-f3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570293\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=QHw3tPbypuVgGRyqMv1F9uSyRIdpUZhmbLytaIEXWmyWULI-L9iFaFsyqjGn0t3Wz-bmCR0ckgqJoJgckXIrXCD66COe4Mj57bAvNrEXMMrRwm~ZsnvFKXQmr2zcbNd9VmndYRb6GpKTd31ax8ifinj3i1ERJIAgvEXr-9ASIskkF2jDYCT-6~q4T2teqozaMJ6Ok2fen4kZxunK4hIWbRd9eKu99JPH-8J8tOOqNtbMPd0YV61oBmGrMUzVHKqjXhdq5HlLG8Owr1jmbgWZdgrgjzVJDEPxQwaYW9--sU1MPN51l4E2dTVxD1lSCShdAJC52GEglu3DhiyuLNLIOw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570293&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy cluster MS 1358 (<em>z</em> = 0.33) imaged with <em>HST</em>/ACS. We number the multiply lensed images used and uncovered in this work. The overlaid white critical curve corresponds to system 1, the red dropout galaxy at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 (found by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. 1997</a>), enclosing a critical area of an effective Einstein radius of \u2243100 kpc at the redshift of this cluster. Interior to this, the blue critical curves correspond to systems 3, 4, 5, at a lower redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2. Additional less secure candidate systems (marked with \u2018c\u2019) have similar appearance but are not well reproduced by our best-fitting solution, and were not used to constrain the model. We also show the approximate location of two unverified candidate <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 7.5 multiple-systems, marked with \u2018z\u2019 (Richard et al. 2008). These were not used to constrain the model but their locations and claimed high redshift are plausible in the context of our model, see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.1</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=hUf1DqygaZgFPRwilIzY-8PSDwMVawY8t4a87bYKDXIvCx3g-ei67HXE2oI1wVrV9C84WTbN1vYKW-gHrFN-oRNODbGxQi8D5yDBjJKuhA5qjE~IUarLm98ekPc58G0HNilHjbkfSRatvF9wZ~KUL~WWAqowCzgGDD8PETBQpEa1kNJHgeCuYdrWaDq2Q2YzHqp74JPccXh8U5qlO-e9UsXBCSIv-lnvFZBKjsEVPv8sztY33IakMFCWsVlt7mF~wTgbuQQcU1kbRs4vFcp~WmPHGMBFKltNL8bMMfTSDPd7V70BUNPbJFHJ~6QGBOwSQZaqw~7gPKiVSs38QrEbLA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Galaxy cluster MS 1358 (z = 0.33) imaged with HST/ACS. The overlaid white critical curve corresponds to system 1, the red dropout galaxy at zs = 4.92 (found by Franx et al. 1997), enclosing a critical area of an effective Einstein radius of \u2243100 kpc at the redshift of this cluster. Interior to this, the blue critical curves correspond to systems 3, 4, 5, at a lower redshift of zs\u223c 2. Additional less secure candidate systems (marked with \u2018c\u2019) have similar appearance but are not well reproduced by our best-fitting solution, and were not used to constrain the model. We number the multiply lensed images used and uncovered in this work. The overlaid white critical curve corresponds to system 1, the red dropout galaxy at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 (found by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. 1997</a>), enclosing a critical area of an effective Einstein radius of \u2243100 kpc at the redshift of this cluster.
