Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>), and a 20-arcsec bar is overplotted.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"16570295\" scrollto-destination=\"16570295\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=YB4sNrHoC9lE2JxYyo6lVRc~FCwlZSVG9FStaBj6kQkjxXEJXOYOfO~EjpjFwgYYcn4D1qBxEFnkq~gP07wBld0UTcFPp2uF5kzJF2F94U4Jq2vyjvMmxMDNV9rAEXFovyK32yv9Ve9xljHSpUzFHbCV-dYDz2rfcga5h7hEwv4nyMNlpV3wDbrxq9x8h2mJ0MBpXAP63SEHa-FX10eNv-2RQPABHUbmlV~7SZAtPG5CWEpqaHOWyEARR0uIjlEIdwblh1WaHTZGocEMJqZC1ZwAVrwcJ8rTr-kNbjsoU-7mIk6lTZg9kW3ubVrEHwWMU0ZVtwpoacjctpVXt~F4bQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Radial surface mass density (\u03ba) profile in units of the critical surface density (for a fiducial redshift of zs = 4.92), derived using the sets of multiple images shown in Fig. 3. The cyan shaded curve is derived by our modelling method (Zitrin et al. 2009b), while the dashed black lines are derived using the non-parametric technique of Liesenborgs et al. (2006). As can be seen, the profiles agree very well in the region of interest, and are rather flat. We measure a profile slope of only d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.19 \u00b1 0.05 within the effective Einstein radius for system 1 (rE = 21 \u00b1 3 arcsec; \u2243100 kpc, marked with a vertical black line), increasing to d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.33 \u00b1 0.05 within twice the critical range, \u2243200 kpc. Note that the inner profiles are at a level close to the critical density (\u00b10.25) for system 1. For comparison, overplotted with blue dot\u2013dashed lines are kappa profiles for three other well-known clusters: Abell 1703, Cl 0024 and Abell 1689, after correcting for the different lens distances. These were slightly shifted upwards on the y-axis to allow a clean view and to better demonstrate the slope difference of MS 1358 from these typical lensing clusters which exhibit a common mass slope of d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u223c\u22120.5.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570295/mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570295\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=g0saIHyZPvk3l6-ZMTpiRjJNaVglsngXbzOB5x2ZHAxTpdDPPxUbCGqHu1GuysgN5x~9FJ9qr98ZNOPiT9N0GfEp~5FKTWqFTpjTU5xqWO00hJUkrcVON-oOb91gHj9jNJ0kumR~DfLDFuR1FWr6R37LIKd-rt69gJUOp2HZyT7KEiPakhNgWFZqYOjvNQT8rXKD3Z-NQOzoK7HDo5E1WGuduYGSsc4uEY6218PO5W5uJ3nQ9vgg3Wo~jrwtrOziK-VvxvlyxuO7UBXYf2BOF3gL5PMPLcLXrKlwgElFd-rV8-W-8-hnfgoPfbevRXZhA8j3~cFctJ7HdCkgiy-clQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570295&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Radial surface mass density (\u03ba) profile in units of the critical surface density (for a fiducial redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92), derived using the sets of multiple images shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>. The cyan shaded curve is derived by our modelling method (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>), while the dashed black lines are derived using the non-parametric technique of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. (2006)</a>. As can be seen, the profiles agree very well in the region of interest, and are rather flat. We measure a profile slope of only d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.19 \u00b1 0.05 within the effective Einstein radius for system 1 (<em>r</em><sub>E</sub> = 21 \u00b1 3 arcsec; \u2243100 kpc, marked with a vertical black line), increasing to d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.33 \u00b1 0.05 within twice the critical range, \u2243200 kpc. Note that the inner profiles are at a level close to the critical density (\u00b10.25) for system 1. For comparison, overplotted with blue dot\u2013dashed lines are kappa profiles for three other well-known clusters: Abell 1703, Cl 0024 and Abell 1689, after correcting for the different lens distances. These were slightly shifted upwards on the <em>y</em>-axis to allow a clean view and to better demonstrate the slope difference of MS 1358 from these typical lensing clusters which exhibit a common mass slope of d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u223c\u22120.5.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=YB4sNrHoC9lE2JxYyo6lVRc~FCwlZSVG9FStaBj6kQkjxXEJXOYOfO~EjpjFwgYYcn4D1qBxEFnkq~gP07wBld0UTcFPp2uF5kzJF2F94U4Jq2vyjvMmxMDNV9rAEXFovyK32yv9Ve9xljHSpUzFHbCV-dYDz2rfcga5h7hEwv4nyMNlpV3wDbrxq9x8h2mJ0MBpXAP63SEHa-FX10eNv-2RQPABHUbmlV~7SZAtPG5CWEpqaHOWyEARR0uIjlEIdwblh1WaHTZGocEMJqZC1ZwAVrwcJ8rTr-kNbjsoU-7mIk6lTZg9kW3ubVrEHwWMU0ZVtwpoacjctpVXt~F4bQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Radial surface mass density (\u03ba) profile in units of the critical surface density (for a fiducial redshift of zs = 4.92), derived using the sets of multiple images shown in Fig. 3. The cyan shaded curve is derived by our modelling method (Zitrin et al. 2009b), while the dashed black lines are derived using the non-parametric technique of Liesenborgs et al. (2006). As can be seen, the profiles agree very well in the region of interest, and are rather flat. We measure a profile slope of only d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.19 \u00b1 0.05 within the effective Einstein radius for system 1 (rE = 21 \u00b1 3 arcsec; \u2243100 kpc, marked with a vertical black line), increasing to d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.33 \u00b1 0.05 within twice the critical range, \u2243200 kpc. Note that the inner profiles are at a level close to the critical density (\u00b10.25) for system 1. For comparison, overplotted with blue dot\u2013dashed lines are kappa profiles for three other well-known clusters: Abell 1703, Cl 0024 and Abell 1689, after correcting for the different lens distances. These were slightly shifted upwards on the y-axis to allow a clean view and to better demonstrate the slope difference of MS 1358 from these typical lensing clusters which exhibit a common mass slope of d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u223c\u22120.5.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570295/mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570295\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=g0saIHyZPvk3l6-ZMTpiRjJNaVglsngXbzOB5x2ZHAxTpdDPPxUbCGqHu1GuysgN5x~9FJ9qr98ZNOPiT9N0GfEp~5FKTWqFTpjTU5xqWO00hJUkrcVON-oOb91gHj9jNJ0kumR~DfLDFuR1FWr6R37LIKd-rt69gJUOp2HZyT7KEiPakhNgWFZqYOjvNQT8rXKD3Z-NQOzoK7HDo5E1WGuduYGSsc4uEY6218PO5W5uJ3nQ9vgg3Wo~jrwtrOziK-VvxvlyxuO7UBXYf2BOF3gL5PMPLcLXrKlwgElFd-rV8-W-8-hnfgoPfbevRXZhA8j3~cFctJ7HdCkgiy-clQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570295&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Radial surface mass density (\u03ba) profile in units of the critical surface density (for a fiducial redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92), derived using the sets of multiple images shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>. The cyan shaded curve is derived by our modelling method (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>), while the dashed black lines are derived using the non-parametric technique of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. (2006)</a>. As can be seen, the profiles agree very well in the region of interest, and are rather flat. We measure a profile slope of only d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.19 \u00b1 0.05 within the effective Einstein radius for system 1 (<em>r</em><sub>E</sub> = 21 \u00b1 3 arcsec; \u2243100 kpc, marked with a vertical black line), increasing to d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.33 \u00b1 0.05 within twice the critical range, \u2243200 kpc. Note that the inner profiles are at a level close to the critical density (\u00b10.25) for system 1. For comparison, overplotted with blue dot\u2013dashed lines are kappa profiles for three other well-known clusters: Abell 1703, Cl 0024 and Abell 1689, after correcting for the different lens distances. These were slightly shifted upwards on the <em>y</em>-axis to allow a clean view and to better demonstrate the slope difference of MS 1358 from these typical lensing clusters which exhibit a common mass slope of d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u223c\u22120.5.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Note that another small critical curve is formed around the group of bright cluster galaxies \u223c1 arcmin to the south, whose prominence is hard to determine due to lack of multiple images at that region. We note that if this southern clump is somewhat more massive than presented here, the critical curves may merge with the central main critical curves to form a larger more elongated critical region. This however does not seem probable as only few arcs are seen in between, and thus rule out the existence of such an extended critical curve.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Several mass models have been created in earlier work, describing the critical curves and mass distribution based only on system 1 (<em>z</em> = 4.92). <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. (1997)</a> used isothermal potentials with which they were able to reconstruct the images of this system. They find an Einstein radius of 21 arcsec, similar to our result. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen (1998)</a> has calculated a total mass of 8.27 \u00d7 10<sup>13</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> with 20 per cent uncertainty, within a radius of 121 kpc (25.5 arcsec), in good agreement with our result considering the Einstein radius difference. Other mass models made for this cluster based on projected WL profiles and circular symmetry, derive similar or slightly smaller values (see e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b46\" data-open=\"b46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hoekstra et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hoekstra 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Arabadjis et al. 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b27\" data-open=\"b27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Diaferio, Geller &amp; Rines 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b85\" data-open=\"b85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Takahashi &amp; Chiba 2007</a>; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b79\" data-open=\"b79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Saha et al. 2001</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It should be stressed that the multiple images found here are accurately reproduced by our model and are not simple identifications by eye. The parametric method of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. (2009b)</a> has been shown in many cases to have the predictive power to find multiple images in clusters. Due to the small number of parameters, this model is initially well constrained enabling a reliable identification of other multiple images in the field, which are then used to fine-tune the mass model. We now detail each multiply lensed system in turn, as listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"16570299\" scrollto-destination=\"16570299\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple-image systems and candidates used and uncovered by our model. For more detailed information on each system and other optional members, see the corresponding subsection. The columns are arc ID; RA and Dec. in J2000.0; 95 per cent confidence level minimal and maximal photo-<em>z</em>; best photo-<em>z</em>; <em>z</em><sub>model</sub>, the redshift predicted by the mass model; comments. Note that system 1 was uncovered by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. (1997)</a> who measured its redshift spectroscopically, which is the value given below. Note also that unusually large errors in the photo-<em>z</em> imply a bimodal distribution. In such cases, the values which agree with the SL model can be different than specified in the best photo-<em>z</em> column, as they arise from another peak in the distribution. Such cases are specified in the comments.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>ARC\u00a0</td><td>RA\u00a0</td><td>Dec.\u00a0</td><td>Min href=\"/view-large/16570299\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple-image systems and candidates used and uncovered by our model. For more detailed information on each system and other optional members, see the corresponding subsection. The columns are arc ID; RA and Dec. in J2000.0; 95 per cent confidence level minimal and maximal photo-<em>z</em>; best photo-<em>z</em>; <em>z</em><sub>model</sub>, the redshift predicted by the mass model; comments. Note that system 1 was uncovered by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. (1997)</a> who measured its redshift spectroscopically, which is the value given below. Note also that unusually large errors in the photo-<em>z</em> imply a bimodal distribution. In such cases, the values which agree with the SL model can be different than specified in the best photo-<em>z</em> column, as they arise from another peak in the distribution. Such cases are specified in the comments.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>ARC\u00a0</td><td>RA\u00a0</td><td>Dec.\u00a0</td><td>Min 0.2\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>c1a\u00a0</td><td>13:59:50.252\u00a0</td><td>+62:31:27.06\u00a0</td><td>1.77\u00a0</td><td>2.51\u00a0</td><td>2.14\u00a0</td><td>\u223c3.2\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>c1b\u00a0</td><td>13:59:51.952\u00a0</td><td>+62:31:26.86\u00a0</td><td>1.67\u00a0</td><td>2.39\u00a0</td><td>2.03\u00a0</td><td>\u223c3.2\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>c1c\u00a0</td><td>13:59:47.656\u00a0</td><td>+62:31:18.25\u00a0</td><td>1.68\u00a0</td><td>2.40\u00a0</td><td>2.04\u00a0</td><td>\u2014\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>c2a\u00a0</td><td>13:59:50.354\u00a0</td><td>+62:31:24.84\u00a0</td><td>0.73\u00a0</td><td>5.53\u00a0</td><td>4.84\u00a0</td><td>\u223c4\u22125\u00a0</td><td>Bimodal\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>c2b\u00a0</td><td>13:59:52.638\u00a0</td><td>+62:31:24.04\u00a0</td><td>0.57\u00a0</td><td>4.81\u00a0</td><td>0.78\u00a0</td><td>\u223c4\u22125\u00a0</td><td>Bimodal\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>c2c\u00a0</td><td>13:59:53.585\u00a0</td><td>+62:31:19.68\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u223c4\u22125\u00a0</td><td>Similarly red\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>c2d\u00a0</td><td>13:59:52.644\u00a0</td><td>+62:31:20.19\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u223c4\u22125\u00a0</td><td>Similarly red\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16570299\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System</em> 1: a high-redshift dropout galaxy at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92. The four images of this multiply lensed source were found by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. (1997)</a> who also measured its redshift. Two of the multiple images of this system (1.1/1.2), form a prominent red fold-arc about \u223c21 arcsec south-west of the BCG, next to another bright cluster member (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>). Image 1.3 is a smaller image on the other side of that cluster member, and image 1.4 is \u223c29 arcsec east of the BCG. These images are well reproduced by our model, as seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a>. According to our model, the angular area of the source is \u22430.1 arcsec<sup>2</sup> (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>), and is therefore magnified about a 100 times in area, summed over all four images which in total subtend \u224310 arcsec<sup>2</sup> in the image plane (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.2</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"16570301\" scrollto-destination=\"16570301\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=UxbnWM80b8p3UoZYwdbWwz2MFNCTvM-9GcIW8NdF6ET5cX0F1SNnJnK~pFDDJn0wxlAese0APRgvhKoh3D1OEICycb617eSkurCm2aihGQX6ntF7Dmlr1JWoVxRSgXyKk14R6A8tOQuHc9m-101FJuWuJCz2qLJUawa0xcO6Yz~LSuJRyi3Irf0je-9TZ0JEIGLQSJzUIiDvUwmjzROkWX97xMdUJXgzWo6pvjqHdC3uVkAmISRGX54FqWV7nNRztZIrhTSu7oakEB7S7bNBPPgBWf4pkJWi0Ic6j4~1Gyz6CND1SqjCd-HdK7~ZM2gl8R~X-WvZI-KzdaNeYqz89A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Reproduction of system 1 by our model, by delensing image 1.1 into the source plane, and then relensing the source plane pixels on to the image plane to form the other images of this system. Our model clearly reproduces very accurately the second half of the arc, 1.2, and the internal structure of other images in this system including the prominent internal H ii regions within the source.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570301/mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570301\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=vr6SYKWmQFVFjH~SomVli9-FyXkxpPrbjV9~u7fyXH5k~P2-qf-yu1oV1Qw0qqHFzLDwzAT2oLPU0DdWpNR~J8~zhXUO-Kh08DkL3e0Y7PDNsjOKGjM~tDOj9mTLwGpbLVW4lJhv5hEZCXniG7s~28oDyqg-sNr4i6deptNHl0cYmgC7flrBtV0QBPup7JKbsIw1lp9e0eRBEKHnvRKVPsKp9~c5O5IEtFeYx5rW5TXngq7dnr2sYNPBKaFFbf9o6oQcQ~k85GeeFYdg2a7YFqkeqbvbJiV3iLl7QI1vq4KLx9oM3cEdcSWvp62-sUznLehNKqpX19NkdHbYs84Nng__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570301&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Reproduction of system 1 by our model, by delensing image 1.1 into the source plane, and then relensing the source plane pixels on to the image plane to form the other images of this system. Our model clearly reproduces very accurately the second half of the arc, 1.2, and the internal structure of other images in this system including the prominent internal H <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions within the source.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=UxbnWM80b8p3UoZYwdbWwz2MFNCTvM-9GcIW8NdF6ET5cX0F1SNnJnK~pFDDJn0wxlAese0APRgvhKoh3D1OEICycb617eSkurCm2aihGQX6ntF7Dmlr1JWoVxRSgXyKk14R6A8tOQuHc9m-101FJuWuJCz2qLJUawa0xcO6Yz~LSuJRyi3Irf0je-9TZ0JEIGLQSJzUIiDvUwmjzROkWX97xMdUJXgzWo6pvjqHdC3uVkAmISRGX54FqWV7nNRztZIrhTSu7oakEB7S7bNBPPgBWf4pkJWi0Ic6j4~1Gyz6CND1SqjCd-HdK7~ZM2gl8R~X-WvZI-KzdaNeYqz89A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Reproduction of system 1 by our model, by delensing image 1.1 into the source plane, and then relensing the source plane pixels on to the image plane to form the other images of this system. Our model clearly reproduces very accurately the second half of the arc, 1.2, and the internal structure of other images in this system including the prominent internal H ii regions within the source.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570301/mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570301\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=vr6SYKWmQFVFjH~SomVli9-FyXkxpPrbjV9~u7fyXH5k~P2-qf-yu1oV1Qw0qqHFzLDwzAT2oLPU0DdWpNR~J8~zhXUO-Kh08DkL3e0Y7PDNsjOKGjM~tDOj9mTLwGpbLVW4lJhv5hEZCXniG7s~28oDyqg-sNr4i6deptNHl0cYmgC7flrBtV0QBPup7JKbsIw1lp9e0eRBEKHnvRKVPsKp9~c5O5IEtFeYx5rW5TXngq7dnr2sYNPBKaFFbf9o6oQcQ~k85GeeFYdg2a7YFqkeqbvbJiV3iLl7QI1vq4KLx9oM3cEdcSWvp62-sUznLehNKqpX19NkdHbYs84Nng__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570301&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Reproduction of system 1 by our model, by delensing image 1.1 into the source plane, and then relensing the source plane pixels on to the image plane to form the other images of this system. Our model clearly reproduces very accurately the second half of the arc, 1.2, and the internal structure of other images in this system including the prominent internal H <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions within the source.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"16570302\" scrollto-destination=\"16570302\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=TKO6LYQFBAbewCjgeSbg8ctbOFnoRXUTxVPNAeiziBh9TEYg8uobwJeUSGTub0LmRwmWcMxynCZgLwRSFqMTiPOdTuDS6M~MJM0xOHUO6WKCEsP4ryX-y1ncsnlTZ9gvCF0Qwn4DUHfHH7lUHpKfkW1fUTJcQbXvepxOc6gxOsQl9bF8xGLx-~xzyqy2YbUCkDJWtGVd0qJ4PS8JCSlNFVSYkvBIRq~HMjKaO0C1MlUHlTR3UEfRkXAmI31BuhG5pidfXuNrim0E5HA5zznFLtc2euyFlMgoqV2~knfij9fKUPO4jD2dg6DKPdkTVxNPAnRR7KNb4GXZdy7NKvXNTQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Reproduction of the zs = 4.92 source galaxy by our model, using the RIZ images. The image is reproduced by delensing arc 1.1/1.2 into a high-resolution source plane chosen to accommodate the high magnification at its location. Two blue lower redshift objects were delensed to the source plane in the procedure. Note that the source shape is very similar to that found in Swinbank et al. (2009), though due to the magnification difference it is smaller by a factor of about 4 and seem less internally stretched. The colour-coding was slightly modified to obtain a better view of the internal details, and some noise was removed from the edges of the image.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570302/mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570302\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=rKSrbTGId3ln2Dzgckl2ZyHtvdSTXTZlSnBOVhI6QeTOmSmn4460Tw3nPIOF7dfd7muF7PGA1uLrO-S3d08kwJCXmfpu7N2eLmHVZ-1iJGIPsKnK0FzqUBQJm01IHQTINjLXoqxTTJ-JQsyTy8D~4RXOQG7WNBmDgjDhQZADXExOcxrjyrGQxpGdw0wDiHRzi1-QwIg-5w-PnzS5aZzp~SMH~W5Zw6tVj0a5Z9tAjK61Kohe-8QVMBAhkzIjBvW2laxFGucR1ZdwBS6IvZS16e-jRjUjgEbkePbV-0cBfeGNznkGtCCER0Ycg6fz2PyXf-om7JYMOelnmyGA4o365A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570302&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Reproduction of the <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 source galaxy by our model, using the RIZ images. The image is reproduced by delensing arc 1.1/1.2 into a high-resolution source plane chosen to accommodate the high magnification at its location. Two blue lower redshift objects were delensed to the source plane in the procedure. Note that the source shape is very similar to that found in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Swinbank et al. (2009)</a>, though due to the magnification difference it is smaller by a factor of about 4 and seem less internally stretched. The colour-coding was slightly modified to obtain a better view of the internal details, and some noise was removed from the edges of the image.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=TKO6LYQFBAbewCjgeSbg8ctbOFnoRXUTxVPNAeiziBh9TEYg8uobwJeUSGTub0LmRwmWcMxynCZgLwRSFqMTiPOdTuDS6M~MJM0xOHUO6WKCEsP4ryX-y1ncsnlTZ9gvCF0Qwn4DUHfHH7lUHpKfkW1fUTJcQbXvepxOc6gxOsQl9bF8xGLx-~xzyqy2YbUCkDJWtGVd0qJ4PS8JCSlNFVSYkvBIRq~HMjKaO0C1MlUHlTR3UEfRkXAmI31BuhG5pidfXuNrim0E5HA5zznFLtc2euyFlMgoqV2~knfij9fKUPO4jD2dg6DKPdkTVxNPAnRR7KNb4GXZdy7NKvXNTQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Reproduction of the zs = 4.92 source galaxy by our model, using the RIZ images. The image is reproduced by delensing arc 1.1/1.2 into a high-resolution source plane chosen to accommodate the high magnification at its location. Two blue lower redshift objects were delensed to the source plane in the procedure. Note that the source shape is very similar to that found in Swinbank et al. (2009), though due to the magnification difference it is smaller by a factor of about 4 and seem less internally stretched. The colour-coding was slightly modified to obtain a better view of the internal details, and some noise was removed from the edges of the image.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570302/mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570302\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=rKSrbTGId3ln2Dzgckl2ZyHtvdSTXTZlSnBOVhI6QeTOmSmn4460Tw3nPIOF7dfd7muF7PGA1uLrO-S3d08kwJCXmfpu7N2eLmHVZ-1iJGIPsKnK0FzqUBQJm01IHQTINjLXoqxTTJ-JQsyTy8D~4RXOQG7WNBmDgjDhQZADXExOcxrjyrGQxpGdw0wDiHRzi1-QwIg-5w-PnzS5aZzp~SMH~W5Zw6tVj0a5Z9tAjK61Kohe-8QVMBAhkzIjBvW2laxFGucR1ZdwBS6IvZS16e-jRjUjgEbkePbV-0cBfeGNznkGtCCER0Ycg6fz2PyXf-om7JYMOelnmyGA4o365A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570302&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Reproduction of the <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 source galaxy by our model, using the RIZ images. The image is reproduced by delensing arc 1.1/1.2 into a high-resolution source plane chosen to accommodate the high magnification at its location. Two blue lower redshift objects were delensed to the source plane in the procedure. Note that the source shape is very similar to that found in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Swinbank et al. (2009)</a>, though due to the magnification difference it is smaller by a factor of about 4 and seem less internally stretched. The colour-coding was slightly modified to obtain a better view of the internal details, and some noise was removed from the edges of the image.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System</em> 2: a long faint arc \u223c21-arcsec north of the BCG, next to a bright cluster member. Our model reproduces this arc accurately at a redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 3.4, similar to the photometric redshift of image 2.1. The photometric redshift of image 2.2 is double peaked, with peaks around 0.5 and 3.4, the latter in agreement with our model. In addition, the clearly lensed arc lies away from the BCG and should have a relative high redshift in order to be lensed, further strengthening our match. Another similar looking candidate is seen to the right of image \u2018c1c\u2019 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>), but as can be seen the critical curves do not pass between these images and thus this third candidate is not probable in the context of our model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Systems</em> 3, 4, and 5: these three systems consist of typical blue and white arclets seen in large amounts in lensing clusters. Systems 3\u20135 follow a similar symmetry, as can been seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>. One image of each system appears \u223c10-arcsec north of the BCG, the second image appears \u223c15-arcsec east of the BCG and the third image \u223c20 arcsec to its west. These three systems have similar typical photometric redshifts of <em>z</em>\u2243 2 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), and due to their close vicinity and similar appearance were hard to match accurately, especially in the case of the third images to the west. We therefore note that there can be an irrelevant mix-up with regard to the third image of each of these three systems, but since the distances between them are small this does not affect the resulting mass model. In addition, due to a minor, northwards offset in the image-plane reproduction of images 4.3 and 5.3, we acknowledge the possibility that there are other similar-looking spots which may correspond to these systems, but have a negligible effect on the mass model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System</em> 6: two blue faint images with mirror symmetry lying on two sides of the critical curve for a source at <em>z</em>\u2243 1.8 by our model. Their photometric redshifts are \u22432.0 \u00b1 0.4 and \u22431.77<sup>+0.5</sup><sub>\u22120.4</sub>, respectively, where the first may be affected by the light from a nearby galaxy. Our model predicts the extra small and faint spec on the other side of the cluster about \u223c20-arcsec south-west of the BCG, as identified in the data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System</em> 7: two greenish small images on two sides of a bright galaxy. These lack photometric redshifts due to the vicinity of the galaxy, and our model reproduces them accurately at <em>z</em>\u2243 1.8.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System</em> 8: three blue and white relatively bright images of a <em>z</em>\u2243 2.1 galaxy, following similar symmetry as system 1. Our model reproduces these images very well at this redshift, as seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>. Note in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a> the highly magnified region near the location of image 8.1, which explains its larger appearance relatively to images 8.2 and 8.3.</p>                        <a id=\"16570309\" scrollto-destination=\"16570309\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=pHqjBV-YpVX7KMYzsn1Q~PNsFkk-yUWJGKE9zbV3kIEmVHFLJT55IB4DGlb9NGLi~4BAjHO8lidDTYMv4l8aziUdSlFMzaSbpFx1UxhTNMSc7LsYRj9G-~EbcOIBjdAp7mn2sABxPdvq61FN85NEOI-6bUUNfxjjZGJxuaQ1nkpDmh3DYAqgDC2dpYKHbdAJMT6grTcEh7WevkcYJQj6OU42m07xICgpFSCrUEenLY~FIPXB2HC8VsPLmqMh3XuJ2x-fwUuTO~czPXKhzISJN8FQC7sn4~GmfnZjl6r79XwnCu-Z2J8a6QdUiruw2VMgYbvjeHkOCxNoa1WUrxioVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Reproduction of system 8 by our model, by delensing image 8.1 into the source plane, and then relensing the source plane pixels on to the image plane to form the other images of this system. Our model clearly reproduces very accurately the other images in this system. The clear size difference of image 8.1 compared with images 8.2 and 8.3 (zoomed-in here for better view) is another indication of the high local magnification in that region.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570309/mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570309\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=RAReKDhCbv15g1X0PP4t6A9NvP5~s5m3N8tB4WdON1uev0joFUAA3SwRLSfb9fLB2lzftpWHTgkK00bN-1tIrYzi0sYGUBxbYmpxQGRK36kQD~YPyEuT131zPrZIPbnsjidg2jGVkv9nrqLiwj7a7pCTWMVuWaqNymAWFjdr8-CYIssl8VSFfjSsODk1SSoU3oV6YAscHP00wi1ePPaS0MK56YsMFjWAjpUzafKNffWkJbiilmuLhxrRkWhgWuyaKHJ3pd8F9docuCQ~X7RT~5TJzFDLe2wz9ArhKX77Bgtc1ZljJpVhh~lEV4xRmdLyOO9BwnNMwvcJW5lqUINozQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570309&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Reproduction of system 8 by our model, by delensing image 8.1 into the source plane, and then relensing the source plane pixels on to the image plane to form the other images of this system. Our model clearly reproduces very accurately the other images in this system. The clear size difference of image 8.1 compared with images 8.2 and 8.3 (zoomed-in here for better view) is another indication of the high local magnification in that region.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=pHqjBV-YpVX7KMYzsn1Q~PNsFkk-yUWJGKE9zbV3kIEmVHFLJT55IB4DGlb9NGLi~4BAjHO8lidDTYMv4l8aziUdSlFMzaSbpFx1UxhTNMSc7LsYRj9G-~EbcOIBjdAp7mn2sABxPdvq61FN85NEOI-6bUUNfxjjZGJxuaQ1nkpDmh3DYAqgDC2dpYKHbdAJMT6grTcEh7WevkcYJQj6OU42m07xICgpFSCrUEenLY~FIPXB2HC8VsPLmqMh3XuJ2x-fwUuTO~czPXKhzISJN8FQC7sn4~GmfnZjl6r79XwnCu-Z2J8a6QdUiruw2VMgYbvjeHkOCxNoa1WUrxioVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Reproduction of system 8 by our model, by delensing image 8.1 into the source plane, and then relensing the source plane pixels on to the image plane to form the other images of this system. Our model clearly reproduces very accurately the other images in this system. The clear size difference of image 8.1 compared with images 8.2 and 8.3 (zoomed-in here for better view) is another indication of the high local magnification in that region.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570309/mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570309\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=RAReKDhCbv15g1X0PP4t6A9NvP5~s5m3N8tB4WdON1uev0joFUAA3SwRLSfb9fLB2lzftpWHTgkK00bN-1tIrYzi0sYGUBxbYmpxQGRK36kQD~YPyEuT131zPrZIPbnsjidg2jGVkv9nrqLiwj7a7pCTWMVuWaqNymAWFjdr8-CYIssl8VSFfjSsODk1SSoU3oV6YAscHP00wi1ePPaS0MK56YsMFjWAjpUzafKNffWkJbiilmuLhxrRkWhgWuyaKHJ3pd8F9docuCQ~X7RT~5TJzFDLe2wz9ArhKX77Bgtc1ZljJpVhh~lEV4xRmdLyOO9BwnNMwvcJW5lqUINozQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570309&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Reproduction of system 8 by our model, by delensing image 8.1 into the source plane, and then relensing the source plane pixels on to the image plane to form the other images of this system. Our model clearly reproduces very accurately the other images in this system. The clear size difference of image 8.1 compared with images 8.2 and 8.3 (zoomed-in here for better view) is another indication of the high local magnification in that region.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Other candidate systems and image identification uncertainty:</em> a similar symmetry to that systems 2\u20135 follow can be expected in the northern region of the cluster between the BCG and system 2. Moreover, several images in the west side of the cluster (marked in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>) resemble their corresponding image candidate near system 2, and have reasonably similar photo-<em>z</em>\u2019s. However, according to our model, these candidate systems are not being lensed in full or in their expected photometric redshifts, and we therefore exclude them from our secure identification.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">System \u2018c1\u2019 consists of two bright blue-white arclets which seem to have mirror symmetry (\u2018c1a\u2019 and \u2018c1b\u2019), and an additional similar looking arclet, \u2018c1c\u2019, \u223c10-arcsec south-west of them. These have a photometric estimate of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 2 and as can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a> are north of the critical curve for a such a source, so that they are not lensed by our model. This may be artificially overcome if one boosts the mass obtained by the nearby galaxy, but then system 2 would not correspond to its <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 3.4 photometric redshift. In addition, both this system and system 2 have candidates to the west, which are not generated by our model, since there is neither extra apparent mass nor galaxies between these locations, so the critical curve does not pass between them. One can significantly boost the nearby galaxies to create a mass lump which might produce images at that region; however, it should be noted that such actions are rarely justified and have not been critically required in any of the many clusters we have analysed to date. We conclude that despite the similar appearance this system is not probable in the context of our model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">System \u2018c2\u2019 is a much more probable candidate consisting of four red dropout arclets. Our model reproduces and therefore identifies arcs \u2018c2c\u2019 and \u2018c2d\u2019 as the same system in any redshift in the range 3\u20135. Arcs \u2018c2a\u2019 and \u2018c2b\u2019 are obtained as part of this system only in redshifts higher than \u223c4.5, corresponding to the photometric redshift of arcs \u2018c2a\u2019 and \u2018c2b\u2019 of \u223c4.5. Still, we decided not to include it as a secure system since the redshift agreement is marginal and the distance in the image-plane reproduction of arcs \u2018c2a\u2019 and \u2018c2b\u2019 (from their observed location) is larger than our typical uncertainty.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Systems \u2018z1\u2019 and \u2018z2\u2019 are multiple images of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 7.5 dropout candidates, claimed as possibilities by Richard et al. (2008). In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a> we mark their <em>approximate</em> locations generated by our model (see fig. 12 in Richard et al. 2008). We did not use these candidate images to constrain the model, but verified that they are plausible high-<em>z</em> objects in the context of our model (for <em>z</em><sub>cl</sub> = 0.33, the lensing-distance of sources at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 7.5 is only \u22432 per cent bigger than the lensing distance of the <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 galaxy, so that redshifts throughout that range are plausible in that context).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16570314 id=\"16570314\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2>4.2 Mass profile and high magnification</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We mentioned in the preceding sections that the profile can only be accurately constrained by incorporating the cosmological redshift\u2013distance relation, i.e. the lensing distance of each system based on the measured spectroscopic or photometric redshifts. In so doing, we normalize our mass model to system 1, so that the normalized scaling factor, <em>f</em>(<em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub>), is equal to 1. We then make use of the lower-<em>z</em> systems, in particular the <em>z</em>\u2243 2 systems (number 3,4,5 and 8) and the <em>z</em>\u2243 3.4 system (number 2), whose photometric redshifts we find most credible to constrain the profile.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We examine how well the cosmological relation is reproduced by our model, accounting for all systems with photo-<em>z</em>\u2019s, as shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a>. Clearly, the redshifts of these systems verify very well that the predicted deflection of the best-fitting model at the redshift of each of these systems lies accurately along the expected cosmological relation, with a mean deviation of only \u0394<sub><em>f</em></sub> &lt; 0.01 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a>), and \u03c7<sup>2</sup>\u2243 0.1 for the best model, considerably strengthening the plausibility of our approach to modelling in general.</p>                        <a id=\"16570317\" scrollto-destination=\"16570317\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=iV14ryNmcLBcshPhhVu3vAQ5DzyhBRWKQnz4agCSYHwDWrSx1SNuzVG2g9CH9J68GK9dSncFvk6P4fBQNtilexQDSmvjphfEXq1DZIC7QdW-tWJ1-8ckvJVcvS1KuKd1dqQFT0LxUONxF-5S8pepVJe9G7WTI752dTJ88aIW6-~cxRneTxk7hOFzCbsnoMiiN428-gk7kF-JW8wWFfndDBPOBtkQCCdzSyO0td1Wc7DSHcsZxFTxoEKsQlwi7oSo8YL8cHKjyAh~6RDOsLIjXObx8PaeIWyVuiQULCKEGza4Bc4axCjkNVfBa6eawEOanPgfooV7pAlm-2mDUKj7Ng__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Growth of the scaling factor f(dls/ds) as a function of redshift, normalised so f = 1 at z = 4.92. Plotted lines are the expected ratio from the chosen specified cosmological model. The circles correspond to the multiple-image systems reproduced by the parametric mass model, versus their real photometric redshift. The data follow very well the relation predicted by the standard cosmological model (mean deviation of only \u0394f &lt; 0.01, and \u03c72\u2243 0.1 for this fit). We take an average photo-z for each system, where there is an estimation difference between the same images of the same system.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570317/mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570317\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=nRfAM~0MqjpeeMLpDNS7zUBKPuEhcIyO1KRAI8LNa2H4vgcJlUwbmMjNkImsFty4lhJts-2M5KmwDRZucbTagomhXQnS4L62roa-44iEs6XaEAx2adm4E7fvLbR7NrS8TcpXsR1KiNej9PovSsxu1i3qYlxeBnlWiJFb-k0r81PgkcvP5Hv-PuH2taQMxgCqa2zzfdhag2A8TVimz3Pr1rgw~aG5b-beBpkjmtum7UfGaYg8ZdLEUueRjk-rBdcovTeAGwDjiuaQaRa42PD7iOCNaCtEpFyQrsWVRXZ2-w2HJQ1LYpbLUJkyEAT5mGSSrmg-PfPvvRWk2bomLijKVw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570317&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Growth of the scaling factor <em>f</em>(<em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub>) as a function of redshift, normalised so f = 1 at <em>z</em> = 4.92. Plotted lines are the expected ratio from the chosen specified cosmological model. The circles correspond to the multiple-image systems reproduced by the parametric mass model, versus their real photometric redshift. The data follow very well the relation predicted by the standard cosmological model (mean deviation of only \u0394<sub><em>f</em></sub> &lt; 0.01, and \u03c7<sup>2</sup>\u2243 0.1 for this fit). We take an average photo-<em>z</em> for each system, where there is an estimation difference between the same images of the same system.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=iV14ryNmcLBcshPhhVu3vAQ5DzyhBRWKQnz4agCSYHwDWrSx1SNuzVG2g9CH9J68GK9dSncFvk6P4fBQNtilexQDSmvjphfEXq1DZIC7QdW-tWJ1-8ckvJVcvS1KuKd1dqQFT0LxUONxF-5S8pepVJe9G7WTI752dTJ88aIW6-~cxRneTxk7hOFzCbsnoMiiN428-gk7kF-JW8wWFfndDBPOBtkQCCdzSyO0td1Wc7DSHcsZxFTxoEKsQlwi7oSo8YL8cHKjyAh~6RDOsLIjXObx8PaeIWyVuiQULCKEGza4Bc4axCjkNVfBa6eawEOanPgfooV7pAlm-2mDUKj7Ng__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Growth of the scaling factor f(dls/ds) as a function of redshift, normalised so f = 1 at z = 4.92. Plotted lines are the expected ratio from the chosen specified cosmological model. The circles correspond to the multiple-image systems reproduced by the parametric mass model, versus their real photometric redshift. The data follow very well the relation predicted by the standard cosmological model (mean deviation of only \u0394f &lt; 0.01, and \u03c72\u2243 0.1 for this fit). We take an average photo-z for each system, where there is an estimation difference between the same images of the same system.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16570317/mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16570317\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265660&Signature=nRfAM~0MqjpeeMLpDNS7zUBKPuEhcIyO1KRAI8LNa2H4vgcJlUwbmMjNkImsFty4lhJts-2M5KmwDRZucbTagomhXQnS4L62roa-44iEs6XaEAx2adm4E7fvLbR7NrS8TcpXsR1KiNej9PovSsxu1i3qYlxeBnlWiJFb-k0r81PgkcvP5Hv-PuH2taQMxgCqa2zzfdhag2A8TVimz3Pr1rgw~aG5b-beBpkjmtum7UfGaYg8ZdLEUueRjk-rBdcovTeAGwDjiuaQaRa42PD7iOCNaCtEpFyQrsWVRXZ2-w2HJQ1LYpbLUJkyEAT5mGSSrmg-PfPvvRWk2bomLijKVw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16570317&ar=964883&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-f9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Growth of the scaling factor <em>f</em>(<em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub>) as a function of redshift, normalised so f = 1 at <em>z</em> = 4.92. Plotted lines are the expected ratio from the chosen specified cosmological model. The circles correspond to the multiple-image systems reproduced by the parametric mass model, versus their real photometric redshift. The data follow very well the relation predicted by the standard cosmological model (mean deviation of only \u0394<sub><em>f</em></sub> &lt; 0.01, and \u03c7<sup>2</sup>\u2243 0.1 for this fit). We take an average photo-<em>z</em> for each system, where there is an estimation difference between the same images of the same system.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find that unlike other well-known lensing clusters such as Abell 1689, Abell 1703 or Cl0024+17, which all have a typical profile slope of d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.5 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>, 2010), MS 1358 has a relatively shallow profile slope of only d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.19 \u00b1 0.05 in its main critical region of \u223c[3, 21 arcsec], increasing to d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.33 \u00b1 0.05 in twice the critical region \u223c[3, 42 arcsec] (\u2243200 kpc), as can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>. We compare our profile with the profile derived by the assumption-free method of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. (2006)</a>, overplotted as well in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>. As can be seen, the profiles are similarly shallow and in good agreement with each other. This may be expected, since the profile must be adjusted to maintain the lensing-distance ratio for each lensed system, manifesting the importance of the images found in this work for constraining the mass profile of this cluster.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results of this work will be shortly combined with wide-field WL data to map the mass distribution to much larger radius. The comparison of these two independent methods, in the region of overlap, will provide a further vital consistency check. In earlier work on this cluster, a shallow inner profile was indicated in such a combined analysis, though based on fewer data (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b79\" data-open=\"b79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Saha et al. 2001</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The shallow profile results in high magnification, as kappa is close to unity over a wide central area and thus the magnification is boosted. This phenomenon we have revealed recently in another even shallower profile cluster, MACS 1149.5+2223 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b96\" data-open=\"b96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst 2009</a>), which hugely magnifies a distant spiral galaxy by a factor of \u223c200 times creating the largest lensed images known, as the slope is even shallower in this case related to the unrelaxed nature of that cluster. Another work based on spectroscopic redshifts claims a somewhat more moderate slope of up to d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.3 for MACS 1149.5+2223 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b104\" data-open=\"b104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2009</a>) but still significantly lower than typically found in other rich lensing clusters. In MS 1358, the high magnification is inferred by the distribution of multiple images and their redshifts, and can account for the large bright images of system 1, at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>). We find that the source galaxy is magnified \u223c80 times into arcs 1.1/1.2 and about 5\u201315 times into each of arcs 1.3 and 1.4, so that the source is magnified in total about a 100 times, and is therefore one of the most highly magnified distant objects known.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The magnification values are hard to determine precisely since the magnification is a very sensitive function of the local mass gradient so that in practice shallower models yield much higher magnifications. For example, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. (1997)</a> have used isothermal potentials to find a magnification of 5\u201311 times at the eastern part of the bigger arc (image 1.2 here), and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Swinbank et al. (2009</a>; see also Richard et al. 2008) have found a revised \u2018luminosity-weighted\u2019 magnification of \u224312.5, while we find in that region an average magnification of \u223c25\u201350 times. It is well understood now by most practitioners that the mass profile cannot be appropriately constrained when too few multiple images are used or when they span only a narrow redshift range. Here, our identification of many multiple images spread over a wide range of redshifts allows for the first time an accurate determination of the profile slope of MS 1358, revealing the rather shallow central mass profile.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16570322 id=\"16570322\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-3>4.3 Luminosity of the <em>z</em> = 4.92 source</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Due to the large difference in magnification with models published earlier (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Swinbank et al. 2009</a>), and due to the importance of the object at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92, we calculate our corrections to the original <em>z</em> = 4.92 source luminosity. First, we simply divide the bolometric luminosity published by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. (1997)</a>, \u223c3 \u00d7 10<sup>11</sup> L<sub>\u2299</sub>, by the approximate magnification ratio of the two mass models, to obtain a corrected source bolometric luminosity of \u223c6 \u00d7 10<sup>10</sup> L<sub>\u2299</sub>. Independently, we find that the source AB magnitude is I<sub>814, AB</sub> = 25.67 and I<sub>775, AB</sub> = 25.76 (after accounting for the magnification), significantly fainter than I<sub>814, AB</sub> = 24.0 or I<sub>775, AB</sub> = 24.94, as published by Franx et al. and Swinbank et al., respectively. We then use <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m2\"></span><a href=\"#m2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation (2)</a> of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bouwens et al. (2009a)</a> to convert the corrected bolometric luminosity into an absolute magnitude in the rest-frame UV. This relation is known to hold from <em>z</em>\u223c 2.5 to at least <em>z</em>\u223c 4, and is expected to be approximately valid also at <em>z</em> = 4.92. Following our model, the absolute magnitude of the source is <em>M</em>*<sub>UV,AB</sub>\u2243\u2212 19.5, \u223c4 times a more common value for objects at <em>z</em>\u223c 5 according to up-to-date high-<em>z</em> luminosity functions (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bouwens et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b89\" data-open=\"b89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">van der Burg, Hildebrandt &amp; Erben 2010</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16570324 id=\"16570324\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-4>4.4 Mass-to-light ratio</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We calculate here the central mass-to-light (M/N) ratio using the luminous red galaxies template described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ben\u00edtez et al. (2009)</a> to convert fluxes into luminosities, and measure an <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-mu8.gif?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=zwk8MStWgDjNxGBivElxQFngSKD4yws8FJpynnqrT~2QGk4qxuLPAu4lXuvOwCx1Fc15NX~O2F4yAP7of7YVJNwVHFl8f4NryZ7TJnVj4WZzTlk8Q8PN1HMRAc6AahkmFYDJeYhCt8813NInK-75g~Sbu-r3v5A1DLtjLoo7CkM3SrR0Yd1rjjoq-LPMqQiPjMhUieZ5gJ7O~z5PSlGjF4N5ME1W1pqbAi5F8thbR04DI26E1rqzXbBj2RsZ0vS8W9N2xhtMoQyaUMAKWYobU8by69YZRabgg4BFD~xqGJ5huMynk15JYxvjA1Bpr7raM9XdklDwvz1MQ4VrmsygeQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-mu8.gif\" /></span> ratio of \u2243160 \u00b1 30 (M/L)<sub>\u2299</sub> within the critical curves for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>). We compare this value to the M/L versus Einstein radius relation found in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b99\" data-open=\"b99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. (2011)</a> for a sample of 12 clusters. After correcting for the difference in the lens redshift, this value tightly follows the relation they presented (see fig. 28 therein), which predicts a similar ratio.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We may also examine in detail the M/L of the luminous elliptical galaxy which splits the images of the <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 4.92 galaxy arcs 1.1/1.2 and 1.3 (visible in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>; RA = 13:59:49.47, Dec. =+62:30:47.55). According to our model, this cluster member has a mass of 1.45<sup>+0.30</sup><sub>\u22120.40</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>11</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> within a radius of 3 arcsec (\u223c14 kpc), after subtracting the cluster smooth DM component. We compare this result with the mass inferred by the virial theorem through the velocity dispersion and in the same aperture. For example, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kelson et al. (2000a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) measured a velocity dispersion of \u03c3\u223c 220 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> for this galaxy, which corresponds to \u223c1.6 \u00d7 10<sup>11</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> within 3 arcsec, in fair agreement with our result (we note however that a smaller galaxy may be hidden in this bright elliptical light, slightly affecting the comparison). The light enclosed within 3 arcsec is \u223c6 \u00d7 10<sup>10</sup> L<sub>\u2299</sub>, which yields a small <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-mu9.gif?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=OEw6sKLPUUVplFQpTN0-Fxz0ceL2TMDVLhqPojOwWRInYPWsrv7dW8bCjpxbOxtgUC9y2YFfRNO5JS0Ph81wAkc3wgecCHonwSI221SirUVVWHH~JxQYXXu7IIDxy1ye5S3GisSKIzvyJijl67MAezna9rP9uLwqXUdHwum3C1RoSjgaU3jd6Y9em67WaeQAP8KIzlxYrKVKMwtTCyU2zJAU~1AaxxzYOv6O18xVga9DIDTUPjOQD66Kp-FbsypeXN7v9i17Hf5998i9D8woFBCdfat0b1z40k54d3Pa31-BPEPdsqeS1bS8mng-GUMlKrOoIXTjCvxcKqer8UpOmA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-mu9.gif\" /></span> ratio of \u223c3 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-mu10.gif?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=bSRGAKA7YWn82CZann2wZT5uVx2V-2gTu-xKIee0ELGIPscWJodpVuQOVWJlOK78xcEteGPjw6dZifXVWSQiRq0gD6au6O7fLOypL7ai8zb8-6FeqTMZV2nmA9l51RxBoriVWn9YSQtvG5YyNupA-jgKg1WEb4QXjbAKJFrr2TauxkMXf0Eh~~MRknKe1Dwvrnq3-kiYinkz8vQ1RRVKKFsEZEyKZMxjsqQrLg-n5LFa3gRqL-Wkgzwrq9p3Fuwd250txzHdWSfRFAByNSYuw6ycDvB-A1g2OwNZrlp7J79QgXZitIuGINn7J7285OUXxCpwghEqHKcnvli0Dm1opw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-mu10.gif\" />\u2060</span>, close to the purely stellar value indicating no significant DM out to \u223c14 kpc. The effective radius of this galaxy was found to be \u22431 arcsec (4.75 kpc; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kelson et al. 2000a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) so that in practice we measure in a radius bigger three times than the effective radius, where the DM should be dominant. However, a lower <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/413/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.18252.x/2/m_mnras0413-1753-mu11.gif?Expires=1639265660&amp;Signature=fLXNDyOOILnqoTwIC1i1DdB03fpgShn8FUkx8h3bpN--9oz792yesKGJHXwjSahh83PvNivRbqaxW1fu9uF-TYOGL6DxnAZVTbBKN2~iRj1~T2JRyvZUStSaGgovOZ-fwUK8T9NyE0a3-pKtYUglu-mGxGdBxrEUx30qXlkNmvTDGckz-ZriR5iCB5ATvrC4MRef96-3A-3ZVrHAuVWFUj8MawrEMPDOETwJDi598u2b4ae8aJ6xt7RoZpAWjjg5A2X-H30HaQBs7C5G2MhGYuADonRNyWefUVOvPVZIiHiygbOysKt-R21jOHjBdD1RFHmk-z5sqclDxbQ3Ha9R0Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0413-1753-mu11.gif\" /></span> ratio is not surprising, because we subtracted the cluster DM component from our mass measurement, and the halo of this galaxy should already be stripped by the significant tidal forces in the central cluster region (if not earlier during the hierarchical evolution of the cluster through mergers of subclumps). It is known that about 70 per cent of the DM is stripped from central galaxies also in simulations of massive clusters (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b71\" data-open=\"b71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Nagai &amp; Kravtsov 2005</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16570328 id=\"16570328\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5>5 SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work we have presented a detailed lensing analysis of the galaxy cluster MS 1358 in <em>HST</em>/ACS images. Our well-established modelling method (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b99\" data-open=\"b99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2010</a>, 2011) has revealed the rather shallow mass distribution of the central region by uncovering 19 multiply lensed images which eluded previous detection, so that in total 23 images of eight different sources were used to fully constrain the fit. Though more lensed candidates might be found in this field with further careful effort, our minimalistic approach to lensing involves only six free parameters so that the resulting model is clearly fully constrained by these multiple images. In addition we have uncovered several other lensed candidates, for which it would be interesting to obtain spectroscopic redshifts (as well as to the systems identification presented here) in order to further establish the results of this work.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The photometric redshifts of the newly found arcs throughout the central region enable the determination of the inner mass profile of MS 1358, through the cosmological lensing-distance ratio, and imply a shallow mass distribution manifested also in our modelling iterations so that models spanning almost the full parameter space yield similar shallow mass profiles with typical slopes of d log \u03a3/d log \u03b8\u2243\u22120.3 \u00b1 0.1 (<em>r</em> &lt; 200 kpc). We further tested our results with a non-parametric adaptive-grid method (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. 2006</a>, 2007, 2009), which yields a similarly shallow profile hence strengthening the conclusions of this work. A shallow mass distribution translates into a boosted magnification in the central region so that the <em>z</em> = 4.92 source galaxy is magnified in total \u223c100 times, and is therefore one of the more highly magnified, distant objects known.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our magnification values for this system are higher by a factor of \u223c5 than previous estimates (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Swinbank et al. 2009</a>) based on models constrained only by the <em>z</em> = 4.92 system. Hence the source size, bolometric luminosity and star formation rate are correspondingly \u223c5 smaller, more typical of faint field galaxies based on current high-<em>z</em> luminosity functions (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bouwens et al. 2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b89\" data-open=\"b89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">van der Burg et al. 2010</a>), and with a physical scale of a dwarf galaxy of radius \u22431 kpc. A detailed image of the interior morphology of the source is generated by delensing the most magnified image (1.1/1.2), resulting in a high effective resolution of only 50 pc, thanks to the high magnification and to the declining angular diameter distance above <em>z</em>\u2243 1.5 for the standard cosmology, so that this image apparently represents the best resolved object known at high redshift.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">PI: Postman; <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.stsci.edu/\u223cpostman/CLASH/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.stsci.edu/\u223cpostman/CLASH/</a></p></div></span></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">This research is being supported by the Israel Science Foundation, and encouraged further by the TAU school of physics and astronomy scholarship for research excellency. We thank the reviewer of this work, Prasenjit Saha, for very useful comments. AZ acknowledges Eran Ofek and Salman Rogers for their publicly available Matlab scripts. We thank Daniel Kelson for useful information. ACS was developed under NASA contract NAS 5-32865. Results are based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em>, obtained from the data archive at the Space Telescope Science Institute. STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. KU is partially supported by the National Science Council of Taiwan under the grant NSC97-2112M-001-020-MY3.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16570339 id=\"16570339\" class=\"backreferences-title js-splitscreen-backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list js-splitview-ref-list\"><div content-id=\"b1\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b1\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b1\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Allen</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">S. (!event.isEmpty) {\r\n                        $('.js-' + event.slot.getSlotElementId()).each(function () {\r\n                            if ($(this).find('iframe').length) {\r\n                                $(this).removeClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                        });\r\n                    }\r\n                });\r\n\r\n event.slot.getSlotElementId()).each(function () {\r\n                            var $adblockDiv = $(this).find('.js-adblock');\r\n                            var $adText = $(this).find('.js-adblock-advertisement-text');\r\n                            if ($adblockDiv && $adblockDiv.is(':visible') && $adblockDiv.find('*').length > 1) {\r\n                                $adText.removeClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                            else {\r\n                                $adText.addClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                        });\r\n                    }\r\n                });\r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlspage\", \"article\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlsurl\", \"mnras/article/413/3/1753/964883\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();\r\n                googletag.pubads().collapseEmptyDivs();\r\n            });\r\n        </script>\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n        <script type=\"text/javascript\">\r\n googletag.enableServices();\r\n                });\r\n        </script>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    <script>\r\n        var oupcookiepolicy_siteid = \"journals\";        // the website                                    </span>\r\n                                </span>\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name js-linked-name-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\">Yoel Rephaeli</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input
